headline.main: 'Standard' Heart Treatment Is Hit and Miss

docs.abstract: Researchers, presenting findings at American Heart Association meeting in Chicago, discuss gap in use by physicians of guidelines for heart disease; for number of reasons, notably differences in patients themselves, various doctors and hospitals do not follow guidelines; statistics are given that show measured improvement in survival when standards are followed and speakers Dr Sidney C Smith Jr and Dr Eric D Peterson encourage use of available information and proceedures to save lives; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Important drugs, devices, procedures and operations to treat heart disease are widely available, and American specialty groups have issued guidelines that generally agree on their best use. So, ideally, heart patients should receive the same optimal therapy wherever they are treated. In reality, they do not. Findings from a small number of studies reported at a meeting of the American Heart Association here last week highlighted a gap between what guidelines call for in preventing and treating particular heart conditions and what doctors actually prescribe for them. Differences in how often doctors apply guidelines for heart disease, which is the nation's leading cause of death, have exposed serious flaws in health care.
